title: Do you think that car mechanics and lawyers should make the same amount of money if they work the same amount of hours? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since the United States is not a Marxist state, no. Do you feel a window washer (substitute any job, no matter how skilled or unskilled) should make the same as a mechanic (again, substitute any job) who works the same hours? If the mechanic is one that has the only skillset to make a $5 million 1938 Bugatti run well, then his wages may well exceed that of most lawyers. Marxism is based upon the idea that every man is an equal member of the collective, owes all to the collective (state) and has no individual right to exceptional wages no matter how skilled. It does not take long for Marxism to fail to live up to its ideals of utopianism when the best and brightest are brought down to the lowest common denominator. Marxism has to be enforced as it begins to falter. Neither the human mind nor body works its best under subjugation, only under freedom. Under Marxism, the shoe shiner, the farmer, the mechanic and the lawyer make the same. It does not take a genius to predict that skillsets and production will diminish over time as it is just not worth the extra work to make nothing extra. The United States market is one that is based upon the individual’s skills or products that they can market to the public, with no limit. If that skill or product is novel and desired by the public, the sky is the limit on how much money they can make. That is why Sam Walton and Jeff Bezos, each basically running a general store, were/are among the richest, if not richest men of all time. Their use of capitalism brought the prices of goods down so that more people could enjoy them. Marxism never brought anything good to anyone but the elites in charge of the state.

No, because then we would have an excess of car mechanics and not enough lawyers. Becoming a lawyer takes years of training without pay. There are a limited supply of them. It all comes down to the free market system pricing. By allowing prices to fluctuate freely, incentives are created where needs are most dire. If we have a great deal of need for lawyers, the price of lawyers goes up and, if there are too many lawyers, then the price of lawyers goes down. Price fluctuates to draw people into the career or out of the career naturally. The same is true for mechanics. If we have too many diesel mechanics, then the price of diesel mechanics goes down. Not enough hydraulic mechanics? The price goes up. Not enough electrical mechanics within affinity for electric cars? Price goes up. Too many? Price goes down. The price signals to individuals to change and make life decisions accordingly, naturally drawing people into careers where society's needs are greatest. This is what is also known as the invisible hand. The free market system of pricing naturally increases prices where needs are most dire, causing people to shift and change their behaviors to meet those needs. why do you think it is so many people go work on oil rigs, and hard to work environments, away from your family and working 16-hour days? The answer: money. It pays well because higher pay is required to drop people to the jobs. In other words, it is encouraging ethical behavior (in this regard) by incentivizing people to take careers where demands are greatest. It's not a perfect system, but it's a pretty good system. It has been shown to lift millions if not billions out of poverty as well as achieve enormous social and economic progress in a very short period of time. At the extremes, it can be oppressive, but the core concept of the market system of pricing is a very good concept and works excellently in the day-to-day pricing of goods and services.

Water seeks its own level. We pay people what we feel is commensurate with their worth and we have set up a society that determines the value of their work. In a society where the threat of moving paper is far, far more consequential than the fear of breaking down on the highway the lawyer would always command a premium. We’ve set up society that way, the same way we artificially inflate the price of diamonds by creating a shortage off them. Supply and Demand works. The kind of demand you create depends on the supply and the value of that supply that we’ve attached to it. We call demand that stays the same regardless of price “inelastic”. For example, a diabetic who can’t survive without insulin is going to pay whatever the price is to get it because he doesn’t want to die. When your car breaks down you don’t have a big threat of going to jail but enemies pushing paper can do you a great deal of damage including putting you in jail so the demand for lawyers, while usually much less frequent than that for mechanics, tends to be more valuable. Therefore the lawyer can command whatever price the market will bear. A good mechanic will always get paid more than a shade tree mechanic; the guys working on Formula One cars are not making the same money as the guys working on a Honda Fit in a greasy garage by the Interstate either. In a capitalistic society we let the market decide and only use regulators to insure that within the same sphere the rules are the same. But there is no real way to normalize the value of a mechanic and a lawyer or a doctor or a grocery clerk and so on. So it is almost always wrong to try to “assign” comparative values to salaries. However in a situation where the supply of labor continues to grow while the supply of jobs continues to shrink, water will find its own level. Labor will flow to the area of highest pay based on the capability of the worker - unless acted upon by the employer who seeks to take advantage of the excess supply by lowering the wage to the point where people will no longer take the job. Then he raises it just above that amount and gets all the workers he wants at the lowest price. It’s one reason we need to have minimum wage - because desperate people will suffer almost any ignominy to get any amount of money to survive. They have been inculcated by a system that strives to teach them about the morality of legally obtaining money so they don’t need a lawyer to keep them out of jail while at the same time they are being cheated by the employer who does not care about their needs or suffering. He is taking advantage of their moral training and fear of jail to keep wages low because anyone is replaceable. Mark Twain wrote about this humorously in his book “Life on the Mississippi”. In the book, he learned to pilot a riverboat because the money was so good. However, so many men began to do this that the owners had their pick of Captains and so they reduced the wage until the Captain was making less than a deck hand or the Engineer. In order to fix this, the Captains formed a Union that restricted then number of Captains that could be available for work for a length of time and thus were able to stabilize the wage of the Captain. Nowadays we use “minimum wage” as an inadequate substitute for Unions, whom we have taken a turn against over the past decades. Unions have their own inherent problems. But the entire salary of comparative worth has been discredited many, many times and anyone who espouses it is a true communist and we saw what happened with communists. However, the other end of the spectrum, unfettered capitalism, is just as bad. Remember: Minimum Wage means Minimum Effort.

I’ve worked with many in both fields (even trained lawyers) along with many others. Lawyers have a more effective medieval guild protection of their fees and wages thanks to their overrepresentation in state legislatures, Congress, regulatory agencies, local and state governments, not to mention being the source of judges, they’ve been able to require the use of lawyers and steadily expand the work at premium billing rates for only lawyers. When the government has to require your use, you’re probably not that useful to your clients (that’s the reverse of value offered in a free market.) Auto mechanics have a larger body of knowledge to master that changes much faster than the law in significant ways with many advancing technologies all interacting in new cars and trucks (heavy truck and heavy equipment mechanics are paid more than car mechanics btw.) They already earn in many cases what a basic lawyer from most law schools in general practice earns (comparing law salaries for top law school grads going to work for 1,000 lawyer firms as minions billing $350–500/hr on enormous projects is very far from the reality for most lawyers, like comparing top Hollywood stars’ pay to the tens of thousands with a theater degree who wait tables. For brains, the average IQ’s are actually pretty close except in lawyers’ self-estimation just as mechanics are self-deprecating after being told endlessly they must not be very smart with a reliance on their hands. The mechanics have been wading into much more IT from vehicle software to diagnostic computers under the hood and in their shops as well as PC/Tablet-based software so a much wider variety than what a lawyer uses (word-processing almost entirely) as well as having a deep and functional knowledge of mechanical, electrical, electronics engineering that they develop continually. Unlike legal work it’s much simpler to test auto mechanics’ diagnostics, problem-solving and solution implementation with the physical reality (rather than a judge’s opinion) and that’s a feedback loop most clients wish lawyers had too. With overproduction of lawyers since the 1970’s as author Martin Mayer was pointing out then in bestselling books while even the American Bar Association noticed that by the early 1980’s and steadily fewer people going into auto repair as complexity and manufacturers’ choices (software, diagnostic equipment in the six figure cost, replacement parts sales, etc.) eliminated thousands of independent auto repair shops and raised the barriers to entry far beyond most businesses. So auto mechanics pay is already getting into the $100–125,000/yr range as of 10+ years ago while lawyers’ pay descends, hiring paralegals for half the cost started in the 1980’s and comparable work but a lower billing rate, are converging rapidly. I frequently run into people with a law degree and some experience who fled that work but the only auto mechanics I’ve run into who no longer do that work (many, many fewer) were ones where injuries or cumulative wear and tear (back injuries, bad knees, carpal-tunnel syndrome or arthritis in their hands, rotator cuff injuries, damage from oil and gas fumes, etc.).

I think a person should pay what the market bears for a mechanic or a lawyer and what they feel is objectively “fair” for the services they’re receiving. We’re not going to get into cost-fixing here. Mind you this could become a slippery slope. For instance, we take out the word “lawyer” from your question and then we replace it with the word “doctor”. So now what? Mechanics (good ones) perform hard and sometimes dangerous work. It’s ironic actually that I was asked this question, as I went through automotive school in Chicago in the early 90s (don’t ask why I didn’t stick with it). I went through many months of school and paid a good deal for automotive school. However, think of how long it takes to get a law degree, passing the bar exam (only offered twice a year and not cheap), and all the costs associated with becoming a lawyer. Myself, I drove 90 miles each way to attend law school at night, 3 nights a weeks for over 3 years…while working a full time job. When someone goes to a mechanic, with some exceptions, the solution to the problem is generally known and predictable. With the advance of computers in cars and fancy diagnostic tools, a mechanic can figure it out rather quickly. Law, on the other hand, is not so simple. When a client comes to the lawyer, the possible remedies are very fact-dependent. Sometimes the issue is novel and that makes things more difficult. Also, the stakes are higher. With a car if the part replaced is faulty…you put in another part. With law, my client could be incarcerated, have their kids taken away, go bankrupt, etc. Should lawyers make more than mechanics? Maybe.

It's an interesting idea. It is possible, in a simple society of say, 100 people on an island, that the lawyer’s contribution to the community is just as valid as the car mechanic’s and they both deserve the same share of the rewards such as food, fresh water or coconuts etc. The issue is we don't live in small, pure communist societies, where everyone adheres to the principles, everyone works and everyone fairly shares the rewards. These have nothing to do with communist nation-states, where despite the good intentions and fairness on-paper, human nature results in those in power taking more than their share of the wealth, amongst other transgressions. You also have to appreciate that right or wrong, the more cerebral and brain-oriented work activities are some of the most rewarded, though this is not universally the case. It is scarcity related, in that, an extremely intelligent, educated person cannot be replaced as easily as someone who’s skills take less time, and intelligence to learn. It is also true that the more educated people, in a money-oriented society tend to remain wealthier, as they manage their wealth better. They also - whether deliberately or not - via the system ensure that they stay wealthy and the poor stay poor. One example is poorer people having to borrow more to pay for things, which means they pay interest that the richer person does not, and when they do they find a way to offset that interest against their tax liability. As someone once said, I cannot afford to buy cheap shoes. The issue with the notion that everyone should share the rewards equally is that this amounts to communism, which has been tried and failed in many instances. China is a notable exception but are we to believe that everyone in China works for the same reward independent of their role? No.

Several years ago, I was working for a utility. I’d started in the field making things work, but had moved myself into working for operations and maintenance in a high-tech facility, where I had an office and the ability to play lots of computer games on company time. The industry went through “de-regulation” and the “cut fat” edict went out. Outside consultants were called in and they interviewed everyone working for the company, asking them basically to justify their job. When asked to explain what I did and why I should keep my job, I thought about it and told the truth. Most of the time I do nothing. I show up in the morning, and go into the control room for a cup of coffee, and to listen to what has been happening, find and fix little problems before they become big problems, and eventually get in to my office where I may play a game or read a book. There are a multitude of little things that I do, strictly in that if they aren’t done, they will eventually become a problem, but that’s only a few hours a day When they asked me why my job should be maintained and if my job should be maintained, I told them “I’m not paid for what I do, I’m paid for what I know. This facility has a lost cost of $25,000 per hour. When something goes wrong, the additional cost for the company is that amount. Me, you’re paying $50,000 a year. All I have to do is save you 2 hours per year of down time - and you’ve broken even. Ask around, and see what management, operations, and maintenance thinks of me - do I save that amount of downtime? When something goes wrong, how much does it save to have me here, readily able to troubleshoot and correct problems and how often do I do it? A few years later, I left that job and company, going to work for a company that did work with them. I had to go back for a job about 6 months later, and ran into my ex co-worker who had the same job title, work requirements as I had. He was never the “go to the control room and get a cup of coffee” type of guy, and told me that before I left, he really had no idea of all the “little” things that I’d done without needing to get “direction” to do so. He said that after I left, his phone rang all day, every day, and when he asked why things were going bad so much was told that I had always just taken care of them before they were a problem.

Do all lawyers make the same amount of money for working the same amount of hours? 90% lawyers find it tough to make enough money for leading a comfortable lifestyle. The remaining make decent money but a very few lawyers make genuinely obscene amounts of money. Every profession in the world is like that but yes on an average some professions are more remunerative than others and a great part of this inequality stems from demand and supply and the ease of entering a particular profession. If a lawyer wants to become a mechanic he can probably become one in maybe a year or even less. However, even a college graduate would need to clear an entrance exam then study for 3–5 years in a law college and then pass the bar exam to even qualify as a lawyer. How long it would take for him to start earning anything at all is another issue altogether. The more difficult it is the higher the Income. Doctors get paid a lot because it is very difficult to become one. But even amongst doctors a heart surgeon will get paid double what a paediatric practitioner would get or a general physician. Power associated with a position also matters which is why doctors who deal with life threatening diseases like cancer, heart attacks, trauma surgeons etc make more money as compared to other doctors. Even in IT since data analytics, machine learning, system analytics etc are tougher fields which is why specialists in these fields get paid more. It is similar when computer science is compared with other disciplines. Every year in the US a lot of students who get admitted in computer science change their major after a year into the course because they find the going too tough for their taste. This results in a perennial shortage of IT professionals in the US which is why generally a CS undergraduate will end up getting 25–50% more than other engineering graduates. The demand exceeds the supply. But even then 99.9% computer science graduates will retire without making even 1% of what a Satya Nadella or a Sundar Pichai makes in a year and remember they are professionals and not entrepreneurs. Even in a socialist system where income disparities aren't probably as glaring, a motor mechanic and a lawyer won't ever make the same money. If mechanics were to start earning much more then everyone would start training to become a mechanic and then in a couple of years there would be so many mechanics that the wages would start falling and half of them wouldn't get employment. In a dynamic system every profession achieves its own equilibrium. In fact if mobility of labour was not an issue then possibly mechanics in US would start earning the same as mechanics in China which would be still lower and probably computer professionals in US would get paid less but their counterparts in China or India would also start getting paid much more. Outsourcing would end and no one would prefer to migrate to the US.

Back in the 1980s, I began my first role as a human resources executive. During those years, an activist movement called “comparable worth” arose. Its agenda was to combine all the factors that contributed to women’s pay outcomes in almost any disadvantageous way. This included job content. The market for elementary education teachers, for example, has rarely been able to assimilate every year’s roster of new EE majors graduating. An oversupply of peers depresses everyone’s pay who wants that specific job. Other job specialties that attract more women than men also have their pay depressed due to a chronic oversupply of candidates in the workforce. The “comparable worth” movement called for pay rates to be determined by some method that overrode market forces. If enacted, it would be wildly inflationary. Why? Because the market effects would set pay rates for high-paying specialties requiring years of training and decades of experience and some administrative entity with the force of law would raise pay rates arbitrarily for other jobs that had become favored by the decision to create mandatory market overrides. The cost of goods and services would either remain high or be artificially raised, producing universal disadvantages to consumers. This question repackages the comparable-worth argument. “Someone should choose and dictate pay rates, job by job, according to some formula that ignores market forces.” The comparable worth movement went nowhere, even when it had the moral impetus of women’s advocacy for their preferred roles in society to pay higher on the basis of “gender equity”. The women’s movement failed with comparable worth. Based on that experience, it’s a fair bet that people will be less sympathetic to either car mechanics or to lawyers than they were the last time comparable-worth arose as a social engineering brainstorm.

“From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs.” If an attorney has to drive his car to and fro several offices just to cater to the necessities of the case he/she is handling, his/her driving must be paid by the client, his/her gasoline must be paid by the client, his/her efforts must be paid by the client. That is, the lawyer must be able to rip the fruits of his labor and not be concerned if he/she can still pay for the car he/she is using So as the mechanics tools and equipment depreciates overtime, the cost of its depreciation must be covered by the payment he/she receives from the client. So as his/her labor must be paid for. But the amount that the lawyer needs vs the amount that the mechanic needs isn’t the same. Suppose the lawyer needs $50 to live for food and transport each day, while the mechanic only needs $20 for food and he doesn’t have to commute because he lives just beside his garage. It would be unjust if they are both paid $35 a day. For the mechanic it would be $15 too much, and for the lawyer it would be $15 short. Suppose the lawyer is in his office evaluating contracts from clients and notarizing them. He/She uses his $10 pen to sign these documents. He/She usually gets at least 10 clients a day. This gives him/her headaches and stress. He/She earned $10,000 in a month. Meanwhile there’s a mechanic who just got an engine overhaul job order.
